name: Oh no! More Clichés. Part 6 Multiple Choice Quiz | Idioms and Proverbs | 10 Questions

questions.text:
What name completes this common cliché?
"Keeping up with the ______".
questions.explanation:
Joneses.

	"Keeping up with the Joneses" is to try and live in the same, or better, style than your neighbours or friends.The expression comes from the title of a US newspaper comic strip of the 1920's.

questions.text: A person who is no longer effective could be described as "A lame ______".
questions.explanation:
duck.

	This British phrase dates back some 250 years. It is used to describe a person who cannot meet his obligations.In the US the term "lame duck" is often used for a President or holder of an official position who is coming to the end of his term of office and is not, or is unable to stand for re-election.

questions.text:
What is meant by the expression-
"To see eye to eye"?
questions.correct: To be in agreement with others
questions.explanation:
To be in agreement with others.

	If you "see eye to eye", you are of the same mind as others.

questions.text:
Which word completes this saying-
"To kill two ______ with one stone"?
questions.explanation:
birds.

	"To kill two birds with one stone" is to achieve two purposes with a single effort.This was originally an English expression dating back to the 16th century.

questions.text:
"To add insult to ______" -
Select the correct word to fill the gap in this phrase.
questions.explanation:
injury.

	The cliché means to be unkind or harsh to a person who is already suffering."To add insult to injury" was originally quoted in a fable by Aesop. The saying "to hit a man when he is down" has a similar meaning.

questions.text:
What is meant by the expression-
"A red herring"?
options: They've been in the sun too long
questions.explanation:
A false trail.

	This phrase comes from the way in which hunting dogs were trained.A scent trail, using a smoked herring, was laid for the dogs to follow. The herring appears to be red after the smoke curing process.

questions.text:
Complete this expression meaning to be ready for action-
"At the drop of a ______"
questions.explanation:
hat.

	In the United States it was often the practice to signal the start a fight or race by dropping a hat.The hat was not always literally dropped but held above the head and then lowered to start the action.

questions.text:
What word fills the blank in this familiar cliché?
"To cut off one's ______ to spite one's face."
questions.explanation:
nose.

	This one refers to a petty action that hurts the person making the action.

questions.text:
What is the meaning of the expression-
"Salad days"?
options: Special dates in a vegetarian's diary
questions.explanation:
Of youthful times.

	"Salad days" are the days of one's peak of youthful energy.It also has connotations of being fresh and green (inexperienced).

questions.text:
If someone is behaving irrationally you might say- 
"They have a ______ loose".
questions.explanation:
screw.

	If a machine has a loose screw it is unlikely to function properly.Therefore the expression, which dates back some 200 years, describes someone or something behaving in an illogical manner.
